oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: H.G. Lipscomb & Co. and Charles Nelson & Co. buildings
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: View of H.G. Lipscomb & Co. on Second Ave. A sign with the name of the building is located above the storefront, and another sign for the business is posted on a building. The Pilcher building, located at 144-146 Second Avenue, is to the left and the Charles Nelson & Co. building, located at 134-136 Second Avenue, is to the right. The painted sign for Dudley Bros., located at 132 Second Avenue, is visible in the background. Several cars are parked on the street, and an equipment truck is in front of the entrance. Some of the windows are open.

The H.G. Lipscomb & Co. building, located at 138-142 Second Avenue, is a five-story, Italianate style brick building constructed around 1895. Brackets support the large cornice near the roof. The second and third-story windows have limestone arches, while the upper two floors limestone lintels. Henry Z. Lipscomb Sr. of hardware business H.G. Lipscomb & Co. were the first occupants. The Charles Nelson & Co. building, located at 134-136 Second Avenue, is an Italianate style three-story brick building constructed sometime after 1890. Brackets support the overhanging cornice. The façade includes Doric pilasters, modillions, and decorative egg-and-tongue motif molding. Prominent distiller Charles Nelson purchased the property in 1888, and he designed the building to meet his needs as a liquor distributor. The building housed Chas. Nelson & Co. Greenbrier Distillery, Wholesale Whiskies & Fruit Brandies until 1909. Other occupants of the 134-136 Second Avenue building include Southern Woodenware & Hardware Co. and H.G. Lipscomb. The Dudley Bros. & Lipscomb Hardware Co. building, located at 132 Second Avenue, is an Italianate style three-story brick building constructed around 1890. The building has a dentilled cornice, corner pilasters, and a limestone stringcourse. The window fenestration includes segmented brick arches. According to earlier images of the building, the structure next door was identical to the building at 132 and belonged to the company at the time. Dudley Brothers & Lipscomb Hardware Co. was the successor to Dodd, Dudley & Lipscomb Co., which had been founded in 1883 and located on Broad Street. The new company moved from that location to 132 Second Avenue in 1888. The firm became Dudley Bros. after Horace Lipscomb left in 1890 to start his own business. Previous occupants of the 132 Second Avenue building include Parlin & Orendorff Co., Nashville Produce Co., Nashville Spring & Mattress Co., and W. T. Jordan & Sons. The Pilcher Building, located at 144 and 146 Second Avenue, was constructed in 1902 for Andrew Pilcher. At the time, it served as his offices and grain business. The building is a four-story, commercial-style brick building with two bays. Three brackets support the cornice. A stone inset on the exterior reads “Pilcher.” On July 6, 1905, the building suffered from a fire and required rebuilding. The damage from the fire amounted to a loss of around $146,000. Occupants have included: Phillips, Webb & Co., Smith, Herrin & Baird Mfg. Co, M. E. Derryberry & Co., and Jones & Hopkins Mfg. Co.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Boucher, Jack E.; Historic American Buildings Survey
